Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 04:20AM flb1011 wrote: It might be nothing to worry about at all, but I would keep on top of it and continue checking with your doctor and asking questions.  I had a double mastectomy with expanders on 12/15.  I had a small opening at the incision sight and tons of fluid drained from it and my drains.  A week after my surgery I was able to go to work p/t and do things around the house.  At 2 weeks I began to change.  I was getting more and more tired each day, feeling like I had no strength, unable to work or concentrate.  My doctor kept on telling me everything was ok and this was normal, though I kept on reading on this board how well most other people were doing. Long story short, my husband called our family doctor on the 9th, told him the story, and he had him take me to the emergency room immediately.  Turns out I had a major staph infection, spent 5 days in the hospital again, had to have all the infection cleaned out and the expander removed, and I'm back where I started from.  Tired, in pain, and now constantly throwing up from the massive antibiotics they sent me home with.  Again, my experience I'm sure is not common, but you can't be too careful.  Good luck, Fran

Posts.Content: flb1011 wrote: Today is two weeks since I had a bilateral mastectomy with expanders.  I had read such encouraging posts about recovery, and thought I'd be up and back at work within 2 weeks.  Things have not gone that well. First, I still feel very tired.  I do a little, and feel exhausted.  I'm good for about 2 hours worth of work, then I need a rest.  Sometimes a couple of hours is all I'm good for. As for pain, I still have some, especially around the drains which aren't out yet.  Nothing agonizing, but enough that I'm taking a Vicodin or two a day, and some Ibuprofin throughoutout the day as well.  Then of course the Vicodin makes me tired, and I'm napping way longer than I should. I just have no energy and feel like I'm not recovering as fast as so many of the other people who have related their stores. I saw the dr. today who told me I was progressing well, and my pain/tiredness can be expected, but he made me feel like I was an isolated case to feel crappy this long. Any similar experiences?  Fran Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 10:58PM flb1011 wrote: What can I say?  I am absolutely overwhelmed and touched by all the posts and the time you took to write them. I have learned that we are all different, and that my recovery is just that, mine, and I will just have to let my body tell me what it can do or not do. I own my own business, a boutique, and luckily have a great staff.  They need direction, but I can do most of it from home, so I plan on doing that until I feel better.  I did go in today, stayed about 7 hours, much longer than I should, and I am paying for it.  I will definately do as little as possible for the next two days. I am blessed that I have a great supportive husband who has done EVERYTHING, and all 3 of my kids are home from college. I am going to try the suggestion of taking Advil every four hours without fail, and see how that works.  Also, the doctor says if I have less than 30-35cc coming out of one of my drains today, I can stop by in the morning and get it out, and I feel like that would be something to celebrate. My breasts are just getting to the hard as a rock stage which hurts as well, but I'm finding ways to sit that make it more manageable. All in all, thanks for all the support and great ideas. The cup IS half full. Fran
